title: Kannada Actors Harass A Family For Being Seated During The National Anthem
text:
Next time you’re in a movie theatre and decide to not stand up for the national anthem, think again! We say this because another bizarre incident about a family being bullied and rebuked for the same has surfaced, leaving everyone shocked.

A family in Bengaluru chose to remain seated during the national anthem. This agitated two Kannada actors, BV Aishwarya and Arun Gowda, who started calling them “Pakistani terrorists”. This incident was recorded, and the video has now gone viral with the actors facing severe backlash from netizens.

The video was originally shared by Kannada actress BV Aishwarya on her Facebook account. Her post read: “So yes this damn thing happened yesterday at Orion mall PVR these F****ing so called citizens of India refused to stand while the national anthem was played n we are here as the True citizens to set these Anti-Indians right. Don’t You Dare (sic).”

How Kannada actors heckled a family and labelled them “Pakistani terrorists”

A group of people screamed saying: “Are you trying to tell me it’s their choice when it's national anthem? It is definitely not their choice. I think they should be ashamed as they are standing on Indian soil. Are you a Pakistani terrorist? Look at these guys... look at their faces once again. Standing on Indian soil, not able to spare 52 seconds for the country and you have the audacity to sit here and watch a movie for three hours.”

Who the hell are these goons to intimidate and threaten those who do not follow their dictate on nationalism?

Salute to those few people who stood their ground in front of threatening idiotic goons.pic.twitter.com/75BmveJHez — Ravi Nair (@t_d_h_nair) October 28, 2019

Disgusted to see youngsters not respecting India and our national anthem ... see the resistance to stand up when being rendered in a theatre ! pic.twitter.com/6Yti6795K0 — Karuna Gopal (@KarunaGopal1) October 29, 2019

If you can’t stand for just 52 seconds for National Anthem, you can never stand for India.



It’s good that these anti national people are exposing themselves these days.



People make them famous pic.twitter.com/8yzUq7Lf8E — Amit Agarwal (@AmitAgarwal9) October 28, 2019

Responding to that a woman from the family says: “I am amazed to hear that the opposite of Indian is Pakistani.” The crowd reacts saying they will file a case if they have to.



Several other cases from Chennai and Kerala have been reported in the past

This isn’t the first time something like this has happened. Before this, several other cases from Kerala and Chennai were reported, where the police arrested moviegoers for not standing up during the national anthem following the Supreme Court’s verdict. In another incident that took place in Chennai, seven people were booked by the police for disrespecting the anthem where a group of six men and one woman were taking selfies while the national anthem was playing.

Ameesha Patel, too, got called out for it

In fact, even Bollywood actress Ameesha Patel, too, wasn’t spared and got called out by Kushal Tandon, a former Bigg Boss contestant. Kushal had tweeted about the same, saying Ameesha was busy with her phone while others stood up for the anthem. He even shared pictures to support his tweet. The next day, Ameesha responded to his tweets reasoning out how her menstrual cramps didn’t let her stand up.

I waited for the film to start so I cud address my GirLY problem in the bathroom. Didn't know that kushal wud make it a national issue — ameesha patel (@ameesha_patel) October 26, 2015

Standing up for the national anthem, a choice not a mandate

In November 2016, the Supreme Court made it mandatory for all movie theatres to play the national anthem before the start of the feature film. They made it a mandate for everyone present in the hall to stand up during the anthem. However, in 2017, a Supreme Court bench headed by former Chief Justice Deepak Misra scrapped the mandate. He said, “People do not need to stand up at a cinema hall to be perceived as patriotic.” Again, in January 2018, a two-judge bench headed by the Chief Justice overturned the 2016 order and gave theatres a choice whether or not to play the national anthem.

While the debate on this needs rational thought and a thorough understanding of a citizen’s rights, for now, all we know is that not standing up for the national anthem doesn’t make anyone a terrorist, Pakistani or otherwise.
description: A video of two Kannada actors BV Aishwarya and Arun Gowda getting agitated and calling a family Pakistani terrorists, who chose to remain seated during the national anthem, has gone viral facing major flak from netizens.
